abstract.text: Tells the delegate that the app is now in the background.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Your singleton app object.
If you’re using scenes (see
), UIKit will not call this method. Use
instead to perform any final tasks. UIKit posts a
regardless of whether your app uses scenes.

Use this method to release shared resources, invalidate timers, and store enough app state information to restore your app to its current state in case it’s terminated later. Disable updates to your app’s user interface, and avoid using some types of shared system resources (such as the user’s contacts database). Don’t use OpenGL ES in the background.
Return from

as quickly as possible. Your implementation of this method has approximately five seconds to perform any tasks and return. If the method doesn’t return before time runs out, your app is terminated and purged from memory.
If you need additional time to perform any final tasks, request additional execution time from the system by calling
. Call
as early as possible. Because the system needs time to process your request, there’s a chance that the system might suspend your app before that task assertion is granted. For example, don’t call
at the very end of your
method and expect your app to continue running.
Perform any tasks related to adjusting your user interface before
exits. Move other tasks (such as saving state) to a concurrent dispatch queue or secondary thread as needed. Because it’s likely any background tasks you start in
won’t run until after that method exits, request additional background execution time before starting those tasks. In other words, first call
and
then
run the task on a dispatch queue or secondary thread.
UIKit also posts a
around the same time it calls this method to give interested objects a chance to respond to the transition.
For more information about how to transition gracefully to the background, and for information about how to start background tasks, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
The centralized point of control and coordination for apps running in iOS.
Marks the start of a task that should continue if the app enters the background.
A notification that posts when the app becomes active.
A notification that posts when the app enters the background.
A notification that posts shortly before an app leaves the background state on its way to becoming the active app.
A notification that posts when the app is no longer active and loses focus.
A notification that posts when the app is about to terminate.
A set of methods to manage shared behaviors for your app.
Tells the delegate that the app has become active.
Tells the delegate that the app is now in the background.
Tells the delegate that the app is about to enter the foreground.
Tells the delegate that the app is about to become inactive.
Tells the delegate when the app is about to terminate.
Tells the delegate that the scene is running in the background and is no longer onscreen.
Learn the order in which your custom code is executed when your app moves to the background.
Ensure that critical tasks finish when your app moves to the background.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Extending your app’s background execution time

abstract.text: Manage multiple instances of your app’s UI simultaneously, and direct resources to the appropriate instance of your UI.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.

inlineContent.text: Your singleton app object.
